choices.label: The capacitors are in series, so the amount of charge stored on each capacitor is always the same, and therefore the magnitude of the slope shows that capacitor <math alttext="C sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> has twice the capacitance as capacitor <math alttext="C sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The capacitors are in series, so the amount of charge stored on each capacitor is always the same, and therefore the magnitude of the slope shows that capacitor <math alttext="C sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> has half the capacitance as capacitor <math alttext="C sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The capacitors are in parallel, so the current for capacitor <math alttext="C sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is inversely proportional to the current for capacitor <math alttext="C sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and therefore the magnitude of the slope shows that capacitor <math alttext="C sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> has half the resistance as capacitor <math alttext="C sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The linear graph indicates that one or both capacitors are not working correctly. The potential difference across the capacitors should produce an exponential curve, not a straight-line graph.
